Based on my search, here's what I found about Claude Code and Roo Code workflow integration for developers in 2025:

## Claude Code and Roo Code Integration

There is an active effort to integrate Claude Code as a new provider into Roo Code.(no content)This integration is being achieved by implementing the equivalent of a PR that was merged into Cline (the original fork source). The goal is to allow developers to request tasks to Roo using the "Claude Code" provider and have execution traces remain in the Claude Code logs.

## Developer Workflows in 2025

### Claude Code Workflows
The creator of Claude Code uses slash commands ‚Äî custom shortcuts checked into the project's repository ‚Äî to handle complex operations with a single keystroke. He highlighted a command called /commit-push-pr, which he invokes dozens of times daily. Instead of manually typing git commands, the agent handles version control autonomously.(no content)Developers can deploy subagents ‚Äî specialized AI personas ‚Äî to handle specific phases of the development lifecycle, including a code-simplifier to clean up architecture and a verify-app agent to run end-to-end tests before shipping.(no content)Teams maintain a single file named CLAUDE.md in their git repository. "Anytime we see Claude do something incorrectly we add it to the CLAUDE.md, so Claude knows not to do it next time."

### Roo Code Capabilities
Roo Code is a fork of Cline focused on extensibility. Its main feature is "Custom Modes," which lets users define specialized AI personalities like a security auditor or performance tuning expert. This makes it a platform for building a custom team of AI assistants.(no content)Roo Code and Cline are local, open-source IDE agents that help developers generate and modify code inside VS Code. Roo uses multi-agent, role-driven execution, while Cline provides model-agnostic, stepwise planning.

### Claude Code 2.1.0 Updates
Claude Code 2.1.0 introduces infrastructure-level features aimed at developers deploying structured workflows and reusable skills. These changes reduce the manual scaffolding required to manage agents across sessions, tools, and environments.(no content)Key features include hot reload for skills, so new or updated skills become available immediately without restarting sessions. Developers can iterate on skill logic in real time.

### Productivity Impact
One developer who has been integrating Claude Code into their development workflow since August 2025 reports that Claude Code is now mature enough to be successfully integrated into production workflows on projects of various scales. As a solo maintainer of a 350k+ LOC codebase, 80%+ of all code changes have been fully written by Claude Code.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive comparison of Claude Code and Roo Code workflows in 2025:

## Claude Code vs Roo Code: Workflow Comparison

### Core Differences

Claude Code is an agentic coding tool that lives in your terminal, understands your codebase, and helps you code faster by executing routine tasks, explaining complex code, and handling git workflows through natural language commands.(no content)Roo Code (fork of Cline) is a VSCode Extension that's getting more and more popular. It's open-source, doesn't opine about the models, is fully customizable, and has a really nice agent as well.

### Workflow Characteristics

**Claude Code:**
- "If Roo is your collaborative pair programmer, Claude Code is your surgical specialist." It's incredibly good at doing exactly what you ask with high accuracy. Because it's a CLI tool, it's also scriptable.
- This is a huge deal for enterprise workflows. You can integrate Claude Code into your GitHub Actions to automatically refactor code on a pull request or write documentation for new functions. This level of automation is something Roo can't easily match.
- To address AI amnesia, teams maintain a single file named CLAUDE.md in their git repository. "Anytime we see Claude do something incorrectly we add it to the CLAUDE.md, so Claude knows not to do it next time."

**Roo Code:**
- You can plug in your OpenRouter keys, Anthropic keys, and even connect it to Claude Code. Mode Switching is a killer feature‚Äîyou can plan in Architect mode, make it perfect, and then it will automatically switch to Code mode and start executing the task.
- Compatible with any OpenAI-compatible or custom models and APIs, Roo Code offers customizable modes such as Code Mode for routine coding tasks, Architect Mode for designing systems, Ask Mode for posing questions, Debug Mode for resolving issues, and user-defined Custom Modes.

### When to Use Each

**Choose Roo Code if:** You want a deeply integrated, in-IDE experience. You value flexibility and want to experiment with different AI models. You prefer a collaborative, conversational workflow where you can plan and guide the AI. You're working on a sprawling, older codebase that requires a lot of exploration and back-and-forth.(no content)**Choose Claude Code if:** You need a highly reliable, enterprise-grade tool. You love the command line and want to automate AI tasks in your scripts and CI/CD pipelines. You're working primarily with modern web stacks and want top-tier performance without a lot of tinkering. Your priority is surgical precision over conversational exploration.

### Using Both Together

Some of the smartest devs use both tools together.(no content)Developers are combining Claude Code, Roo Code, and Cursor to supercharge their development process.

### Recent Updates (2025-2026)

Claude Code 2.1.0 arrives in the midst of a significant shift in developer behavior. Originally built as an internal tool at Anthropic, Claude Code is now gaining real traction among external power users‚Äîespecially those building autonomous workflows, experimenting with agent tooling, and integrating Claude into terminal-based pipelines.(no content)New features include hot reload for skills, so new or updated skills become available immediately without restarting sessions. Developers can iterate on skill logic in real time, eliminating stop-start friction.

We're building a superset | Hacker News","url":"https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=43642212"},{"title":"Programming with AI using Claude Code, Roo Code & Cursor ü§ñ ‚Ä¢ Pedro Martins","url":"https://nikuscs.com/blog/10-ai-workflow-with-claude-code-roocode-gpt/"},{"title":"AI Coding Tools: What Works (and What Doesn‚Äôt) for Me | by Aleksandar Mirilovic | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@amirilovic/ai-coding-tools-what-works-and-what-doesnt-for-me-56be3d3c1018"}]

Based on the search results, here's what developers are saying about Roo Code vs Claude Code in 2025:

## Key Differences

### Roo Code
- Roo Code is an open-source VS Code extension that puts an entire AI development team right in your code editor for autonomous coding.
- Roo offers more control and a better coding experience overall.
- It's open-source, doesn't opine about the models, is fully customizable, and you can actually contribute and help shape its future, fork it, or do whatever you want with it.
- Roo has a "Mode Switching" feature where you can plan in Architect mode, make it perfect, and then it will switch automatically to Code mode and start executing the task.
- Flexibility is a key advantage - when one AI model is "acting senile" (as one Redditor put it), you can swap it out for another one in seconds.
- The downside is it can be a token-guzzler, especially on big projects. Since you're paying for API calls to whatever model you're using, big refactoring tasks can get pricey.

### Claude Code
- Claude Code is an AI-powered coding assistant that lives in your terminal, helping developers write and debug code faster through natural language.
- If Roo is your collaborative pair programmer, Claude Code is your surgical specialist. It's incredibly good at just doing the thing you ask it to do, with a high degree of accuracy.
- Claude Code is known for making surgical, necessary corrections without adding a bunch of fluff, which saves time and reduces the risk of introducing new bugs.
- Because it's a CLI tool, it's scriptable. This is a huge deal for enterprise workflows - you can integrate Claude Code into GitHub Actions to automatically refactor code on a pull request or write documentation for new functions.
- Claude Code feels really powerful, but it does need some set-up‚Äîespecially on Windows where you'll have to use WSL. Once you get past the learning curve, it shines.

## Developer Opinions from Forums

One developer noted: "I've dabbled with both‚ÄîAPI with Roo and ClaudeCode. Claude Code has an edge in performance, especially since there's no rate limiting. But Roo offers more control and a better coding experience overall. Just be aware of the costs associated with API use; it can add up fast. If you want something that tackles everything in one go, Claude Code is the route to take, but if you prefer customization, Roo might be your best bet."(no content)On Hacker News, one user compared the two directly: "I asked Claude Code to [create documentation] with the same prompt. It created several markdown files with half a dozen mermaid diagrams describing the tech stack, the architecture, the data model and so much more."(no content)However, some developers prefer Roo: "In my experience, Roo and Cline are actually outpacing CC, which surprised me! I tried Claude Max but found myself going back to Cline for better performance and less hassle. Sometimes, I feel like I have to wrestle with CC just to get it to listen to me."

## Pricing Comparison

- Claude Code's Free plan lets you try Claude on web, mobile, and desktop with basic chat and code generation features. Pro costs $17 per month when billed annually, or $20 monthly.
- Claude Max costs $100/month for heavy usage without rate limits.
- Roo Code's Cloud Free plan costs nothing and includes token usage tracking. For advanced users, Pro costs $20 per month plus $5 per hour for cloud tasks.

## Bottom Line

The industry is moving toward increasingly automated development flows with less human involvement. For now, the sweet spot lies in tools that integrate seamlessly with IDEs while still offering strong automation ‚Äî with Claude Code being considered the best option by some developers.(no content)Both Roo and Claude are considered two of the best AI coding tools available, and the fact that Roo Code, an open-source project, can stand toe-to-toe with a powerhouse like Anthropic is seen as a huge win for the developer community.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Claude Code and Roo Code handoff workflow best practices for developers:

## Handoff Workflow Best Practices in Claude Code

### Smart Handoff Commands

Smart Handoff is a Claude Code command that captures both your direction and your details before compaction, so you can resume exactly where you left off.(no content)When you sense your context filling (~70‚Äì80% usage), run it.

### Context Management for Handoffs

One developer recommends doing a handoff or compact when reaching total 60% context usage if building something complex.(no content)Often when the context window starts getting full or the model is struggling with a complex task, starting a new conversation using /clear is recommended. Claude provides /compact which runs faster, but sometimes it's preferred to make Claude write what happened in the current session before killing it and starting a new one.

### Session Handoff Feature Request

Currently, Claude CLI sessions are stateless. When a session ends, context and pending tasks are lost unless manually documented by the user.(no content)Multi-day workflows require users to manually brief Claude at session start.

A proposed solution involves handoff files that are Claude-specific context (what Claude needs to know), living in the .claude/ directory (gitignored by default, optional to commit), with tighter integration where Claude reads/writes directly without external tools.

### Subagent Handoff Best Practices

Give each subagent one clear goal, input, output, and handoff rule. Keep descriptions action-oriented ("Use after a spec exists; produce an ADR and guardrails").(no content)At PubNub, subagents + hooks turn Claude Code from a helpful AI into a repeatable engineering system, enabling faster onboarding, safer automation, and clean handoffs while keeping humans firmly in the loop.

### The Handoff Pattern vs. Tool Delegation

The handoff pattern represents a different philosophy of agent collaboration compared to tool delegation. When an agent uses another agent as a tool, it's essentially asking for help while maintaining responsibility for the final response. When an agent performs a handoff, it's saying "this other agent is better equipped to handle this entire conversation from here on."

### Session Teleportation (New in v2.1.0)

Session teleportation via /teleport and /remote-env slash commands allows claude.ai subscribers to resume and configure remote sessions. Developers can seamlessly move work between local terminals and the web interface ‚Äî ideal for switching devices or sharing sessions with collaborators.

### CLAUDE.md for Team Continuity

To address AI amnesia, teams maintain a single file named CLAUDE.md in their git repository. "Anytime we see Claude do something incorrectly we add it to the CLAUDE.md, so Claude knows not to do it next time."

Automating Projects with AI Agent‚Ä¶ | by Nayib | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/thedeephub/basic-guide-to-roo-code-579facefedbe"},{"title":"How I Effectively Use Roo Code for AI-Assisted Development","url":"https://spin.atomicobject.com/roo-code-ai-assisted-development/"},{"title":"RooCode-Tips-Tricks/personal_roo_docs/technical/custom-modes.md at main ¬∑ Michaelzag/RooCode-Tips-Tricks","url":"https://github.com/Michaelzag/RooCode-Tips-Tricks/blob/main/personal_roo_docs/technical/custom-modes.md"},{"title":"Roo Code Docs | Roo Code Documentation","url":"https://docs.roocode.com/"},{"title":"Custom Instructions | Roo Code Documentation","url":"https://docs.roocode.com/features/custom-instructions"},{"title":"switch_mode | Roo Code Documentation","url":"https://docs.roocode.com/advanced-usage/available-tools/switch-mode"}]

Here are the search results for "Roo Code custom modes workflow examples architects developers":

## Roo Code Custom Modes: Workflow Examples for Architects and Developers

Roo Code allows you to create custom modes to tailor Roo's behavior to specific tasks or workflows.(no content)Custom modes can be either global (available across all projects) or project-specific (defined within a single project).

### Built-in Modes

You can override Roo Code's built-in modes (like üíª Code, ü™≤ Debug, ‚ùì Ask, üèóÔ∏è Architect, ü™É Orchestrator) with customized versions.(no content)This is done by creating a custom mode with the same slug as a default mode (e.g., code, debug).

### Workflow Optimization

Starting in Architect mode is recommended. When you do this, Roo will craft an implementation plan that can be referenced by you, but more importantly by future Roo tasks to maintain project context.(no content)Different modes have specific file type restrictions - for example, Architect Mode can only edit files matching the .md extension. After completing architecture planning in Architect mode, Roo switches to Code mode to implement the designed features. When encountering bugs during development, Roo switches from Code mode to Debug mode for systematic troubleshooting.

### Custom Mode Examples

**Technical Writer Mode:**
You can create a "Technical Writer" mode defined as "a specialized technical writer focused on creating clear, accessible documentation for developers and end-users" with expertise in "technical accuracy, information architecture, and audience-appropriate language."

**DevOps Engineer Mode:**
A "DevOps Engineer" mode can be created as "a DevOps engineer specialized in CI/CD pipelines, infrastructure as code, and deployment automation" that excels at "creating scalable, maintainable deployment solutions and developer workflows."

**Test Engineer Mode:**
A Test Engineer mode can be created with expertise in "writing comprehensive test suites, test-driven development, integration testing, and performance testing."

### Key Features for Workflows

Each mode‚Äîincluding custom ones‚Äîfeatures Sticky Models. This means Roo Code automatically remembers and selects the last model you used with a particular mode. This lets you assign different preferred models to different tasks without constant reconfiguration.(no content)Different modes have different permissions - while Architect mode is read-only on your project, Code mode has access to all tools like editing, terminal commands, and MCPs. You can configure different AI models and settings to specific modes, like using o3 for architecture planning and Claude Sonnet 4 for code execution.

### Sharing and Collaboration

The export feature lets you export any mode‚Äîand its associated rules‚Äîinto a single, portable YAML file that you can import into any project. This allows you to package a mode and its rules into one file to easily share with your team.(no content)You can visit the Roo Code Marketplace to browse and install community-contributed modes with a single click. The marketplace offers specialized modes for various tasks like React development, documentation writing, testing, and more.

We did the Math for you","url":"https://apidog.com/blog/claude-code-cursor-cost-analysis/"},{"title":"Claude code pricing: How to save money","url":"https://blog.promptlayer.com/claude-code-pricing-how-to-save-money/"},{"title":"The Hidden Costs of Claude Code: Token Usage, Limits, and Cost Optimization","url":"https://www.aiengineering.report/p/the-hidden-costs-of-claude-code-token"}]

Based on my search, here's a comprehensive overview of Claude Code API vs subscription cost optimization for heavy users in 2025:

## Subscription Plans Overview

The standard subscription options include multiple tiers: the Pro plan, priced at $20 per month (or $17 if you choose annual billing), and the Max plans at $100 for 5√ó usage or $200 for 20√ó.(no content)Claude Max $200 Subscription at $200/month includes all models with full Opus 4.5 access and 20x higher limits than Pro. With Opus-specific caps removed and increased overall limits, Max users have generous all-day Opus 4.5 usage.

## API Pricing

According to Anthropic's documentation, the per-token pricing is: Claude Opus 4.5 (most capable): $5.00 per million input tokens, $25.00 per million output tokens. Claude Sonnet 4.5 (balanced): For normal context lengths (‚â§200K input tokens), $3.00 input / $15.00 output; for "long-context" requests (any request with >200K input tokens), $6.00 input / $22.50 output.

## Cost Comparison for Heavy Users

API can be more expensive than the subscription-based pricing if you are a heavy user, as the subscription offers more API usage for the price. For example, you can get $150 worth of API usage for the price of $20 a month with a Claude Pro subscription.(no content)When your API base usage exceeds $100/month, it makes more sense to sign up for the subscription. You can also do a hybrid approach; get the cheapest subscription and switch to API usage if you hit the limits.(no content)When running the --view monthly, one user saw that they would have only spent $70.46 if using an API key, when actually paying $100/mo for Claude Max. Granted, the month is not over so they still may end up hypothetically saving money with the subscription, but this view is the only reliable way to make this comparison.

## Key Optimization Strategies

Use Prompt Caching: For Claude Code, caching repetitive inputs can save up to 90% on input token costs. Leverage Batch Processing: Claude Code's batch API offers 50% savings on output tokens, ideal for large-scale tasks.(no content)Heavy Users (API): Without optimization, Claude Code via Anthropic API is cheaper ($13.78 vs. $16.52 for Sonnet 4, $68.86 vs. $82.62 for Opus 4). With prompt caching and batch processing, Claude Code's costs drop significantly (e.g., $5.97 for Sonnet 4).

## Rate Limits (August 2025 Changes)

Anthropic introduced weekly rate limits in August 2025, primarily targeting power users. Designed to curb continuous 24/7 usage leading to unexpectedly high costs, these limits primarily affect less than 5% of users.(no content)Max subscribers can purchase additional usage, beyond what the rate limit provides, at standard API rates.

## Recommendation

I recommend starting with Claude Pro if you're new to Claude Code and already use web Claude. Upgrade to Max or switch to API based on your actual usage patterns after a few weeks of regular development work.(no content)The pay-as-you-go model charges based on the tokens processed, which can exponentially increase costs if not managed correctly. The ideal strategy depends on the use case size - smaller projects might stick with subscriptions, whereas large integrations might see savings in token-based billing.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about team development, Claude Code, Roo Code, and solo developer workflows:

## Key Findings

### Claude Code Creator's Workflow (Boris Cherny)

Boris Cherny, the creator of Claude Code at Anthropic, revealed a workflow that uses parallel AI agents, verification loops, and shared memory to let one developer operate with the output of an entire engineering team.(no content)Cherny uses slash commands ‚Äî custom shortcuts checked into the project's repository ‚Äî to handle complex operations with a single keystroke. He highlighted a command called /commit-push-pr, which he invokes dozens of times daily.(no content)Cherny deploys subagents ‚Äî specialized AI personas ‚Äî to handle specific phases of the development lifecycle. He uses a code-simplifier to clean up architecture after the main work is done and a verify-app agent to run end-to-end tests before anything ships.

### CLAUDE.md for Team Memory

Cherny's team maintains a single file named CLAUDE.md in their git repository. "Anytime we see Claude do something incorrectly we add it to the CLAUDE.md, so Claude knows not to do it next time."(no content)When a human developer reviews a pull request and spots an error, they don't just fix the code; they tag the AI to update its own instructions. The longer the team works together, the smarter the agent becomes.

### Solo Developer Workflows

Claude Code's terminal-based workflow eliminates context switching‚Äîthe silent productivity killer for solo developers‚Äîby integrating directly into the development environment.(no content)One developer reported completing three weeks of planned work within four days of implementing a Claude Code workflow, with weekly story point completion jumping from 14 to 37 ‚Äî a 164% improvement ‚Äî while debugging time dropped by 60%.

### GitHub-Based Workflow Pattern

A recommended workflow pattern includes: Plan ‚Äî Break every feature into granular GitHub issues. Create ‚Äî Use Claude Code slash-commands to write the code. Test ‚Äî Run the app's test-suite and headless-browser checks. Deploy ‚Äî Merge the PR; the host auto-deploys.(no content)Best practices include refining each issue manually until a junior dev could deliver it, keeping scopes tiny (think "add password reset email" not "build auth"), and storing research & sub-tasks in a /scratchpads folder for agent recall.

### Team Scaling Challenges

Once an engineer masters Claude Code, their productivity gains are so substantial that the real challenge becomes organizational‚Äîscaling these workflows across entire teams. "Once you have multiple people on your team shipping AI-written code, you have a completely different type of problem... You have to rewire everything about how your team builds software."

A recommended workflow pattern includes: Plan ‚Äî Break every feature into granular GitHub issues. Create ‚Äî Use Claude Code slash-commands to write the code. Test ‚Äî Run the app's test-suite and headless-browser checks. Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Claude Code mistakes, anti-patterns, and tips for developers:

## Common Mistakes and Anti-Patterns

### 1. Pattern Inconsistency
Every time developers ask Claude to create a new model or controller, it can be like working with a different developer - with no adherence to conventions and mixed patterns within the same codebase. One file might use service objects, while the next stuffs everything into fat models.

### 2. Ignoring Existing Code Patterns
Claude doesn't automatically know your existing patterns. Ask for user authentication and it might create a whole new system instead of using your established AuthenticationService. Need error handling? New approach every time, ignoring standardized error classes.

### 3. Context Window Problems
The agent can forget project requirements by its third response, switch between different implementations (like JWT to OAuth to session-based auth), and every correction pushes earlier context out of the window, creating "architectural amnesia." Keeping the main agent in pure orchestration mode prevents accumulation of implementation noise.

### 4. Test Modification Issues
Claude Code is not bashful about modifying tests to be less specific or worse, changing the test to assert the implemented (wrong) behavior. When challenged, it will often say "this is how it should work anyway." Be very wary of changes to test files.

### 5. Jumping Into Code Without Planning
Jumping straight into code is an anti-pattern - it's like building a house without blueprints, fast at first, but problems emerge quickly. Use Shift+tab keys to switch between Claude Code planning mode and normal mode.

## Best Practices and Tips

### CLAUDE.md Configuration
Your CLAUDE.md files become part of Claude's prompts, so they should be refined like any frequently used prompt. A common mistake is adding extensive content without iterating on its effectiveness. Take time to experiment and determine what produces the best instruction following from the model.(no content)Whenever Claude makes a mistake, add a rule to CLAUDE.md to prevent it from happening again. In pull requests, tag @claude and let a GitHub Action update CLAUDE.md directly during code review. Claude auto-loads CLAUDE.md at the start of every session, ensuring persistent improvement.

### Use Test-Driven Development
It's recommended to use Claude Code in a "test driven development" fashion by having it write the tests first. Then, spend a bit more time than usual in review of the generated tests.

### Leverage Sub-agents
One Claude session for everything leads to "context pollution" where concerns bleed together and conversations become unfocused. The solution is to deploy specialized sub-agents with single, well-defined purposes.(no content)Using subagents to verify details or investigate particular questions, especially early on in a conversation or task, tends to preserve context availability without much downside in terms of lost efficiency.

### Efficient Command Usage
Don't waste tokens asking Claude to run commands. The ! prefix executes bash instantly and injects output into context. No model processing, no delay, no wasted tokens - the output goes straight into context.

### Context Management
Claude Code is definitely dumber after context compaction. It doesn't know what files it was looking at and needs to re-read them. It will make mistakes you specifically corrected again earlier in the session.(no content)You can trigger compaction manually with the /compact command, so if you notice Claude Code getting lost, it's a good thing to try.

### Use Hooks for Enterprise Repos
Hooks are critical for steering Claude in a complex enterprise repo. They are the deterministic "must-do" rules that complement the "should-do" suggestions in CLAUDE.md.

### Be Explicit About Patterns
Show exact patterns to follow, list specific anti-patterns to avoid, and leave no room for interpretation - explicit is better than implicit.(no content)Claude Code is a powerful tool that amplifies both good and bad practices. The most successful users obsess over context management (it's the primary failure mode), plan rigorously before coding (vibe coding creates technical debt), and keep systems simple.

Based on the search results, here's a comparison between Claude Code and Roo Code for web development, backend, and mobile development:

## Claude Code vs Roo Code Comparison

### Overview

Two of the biggest names in the AI coding assistant game right now are Roo Code and Claude Code.(no content)They both claim to be able to help you untangle the gnarliest of code, but they go about it in very different ways.

### Core Differences

**Claude Code:**
- Claude Code is an agentic coding tool that lives in your terminal, understands your codebase, and helps you code faster by executing routine tasks, explaining complex code, and handling git workflows - all through natural language commands.
- With support for models like Claude 3.5 Sonnet and Claude 3 Opus, it delivers contextual reasoning and multi-file understanding unmatched by typical copilots. Its agentic command-line interface makes it feel like an intelligent collaborator embedded in your workflow.
- Claude Code is a polished, terminal-based assistant tied to the Claude ecosystem.

**Roo Code:**
- Roo Code is the scrappy, open-source underdog that lives right inside your VS Code editor. It started as a fork of another tool called Cline, but it has evolved into a full-blown AI agent that can read & write files, run terminal commands, and even browse the web, all from a sidebar in your IDE.
- Roo is "model-agnostic." That means you "bring your own key" (BYOK) and can plug in whatever AI model you want ‚Äì GPT-4, Gemini, and, yes, even Claude.
- Roo Code is compatible with a wide array of OpenAI-compatible or custom models and APIs and offers several customizable modes, including Code Mode for standard coding tasks, Architect Mode for system design, Ask Mode for inquiries, Debug Mode for troubleshooting, and tailored Custom Modes for specific functions.

### Pricing Models

Pricing models differ fundamentally‚ÄîClaude Code offers predictable subscription costs while Roo Code requires you to manage your own API spending.

- For Claude Code, if you are a solo dev, Anthropic Pro subscription for $20 per month will get you very far.
- Real-world testing shows Roo Code consumes approximately $50 USD in tokens for comprehensive feature testing. This direct-cost model appeals to developers who want complete control over their spending and prefer paying for exactly what they use.

### Performance

Performance differences are minimal since Roo Code uses Claude's models in the backend, but Claude Code's 77.2% SWE-bench success rate represents leading-edge accuracy.

### When to Choose Each Tool

**Choose Claude Code if:**
- You need a highly reliable, enterprise-grade tool. You love the command line and want to automate AI tasks in your scripts and CI/CD pipelines. You're working primarily with modern web stacks and want top-tier performance without a lot of tinkering.
- You work across multiple environments and need flexibility. You want predictable monthly costs without worrying about API consumption. You value industry-leading performance metrics and want the most accurate code generation. You appreciate CLI integration and automation capabilities.

**Choose Roo Code if:**
- Roo Code excels in the VSCode environment, where it integrates beautifully with your existing workflow.
- Roo Code optimizes for VSCode users with native integration, transparent token tracking, and a pay-per-use model that appeals to budget-conscious developers.

### Using Both Tools Together

Some of the smartest devs use both. They use Roo for the day-to-day, in-the-editor coding and architectural planning. Then, they break out Claude Code for specific, high-powered tasks or for automation.

### User Experience

Some users have moved from Roo to Claude Code and found it simpler, noting it works great within Cursor and is "just a more reliable tool... especially with tool calls and applying diffs."

The search results don't provide specific comparisons for mobile development use cases, but both tools are general-purpose AI coding assistants that would work across web development, backend, and mobile development workflows.

Automating Projects with AI Agent‚Ä¶ | by Nayib | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/thedeephub/basic-guide-to-roo-code-579facefedbe"},{"title":"Roo Code Docs | Roo Code Documentation","url":"https://docs.roocode.com/"},{"title":"Roo Code Setup and Workflow for the best $0 development ¬∑ GitHub","url":"https://gist.github.com/livecodelife/6c97dc64ee1a12687a554ada9dd579dd"},{"title":"Tips & Tricks | Roo Code Documentation","url":"https://docs.roocode.com/tips-and-tricks"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Roo Code's Architect mode, Code mode, and workflow best practices:

## Roo Code Modes Overview

Roo Code offers specialized modes for different tasks including Code, Ask, Architect, Debug, and Orchestrator modes for optimal AI assistance.

### Key Modes

**Architect Mode:**
- Used to plan systems, specs, and migrations.
- Architect mode is read-only on your project.
- It's recommended to always start in Architect mode. When you do this, Roo will craft an implementation plan that can be referenced by you, but more importantly by future Roo tasks to maintain project context.

**Code Mode:**
- Code mode has access to all tools like editing, terminal commands, and MCPs.
- Code Mode generates actual code based on the designs and plans.

## Workflow Best Practices

### Starting with Architect Mode
It's not recommended to ask Roo to do anything you yourself don't know how to do. This may be fine for small things like one-off scripts, but will fall apart if you have to build anything that should be maintained over a long period of time.

### Transitioning Between Modes
Once you've completed a task that was planned by the architect mode, you can start a new task and tell Roo to continue implementing the plan. The end of the last task will usually include a recommendation on where to start next if needed.

### Mode Switching
When switching modes, Roo automatically selects that model‚Äîno manual selection needed. You can assign different models to different modes (e.g., Gemini 2.5 Preview for Architect mode, Claude Sonnet 3.7 for Code mode).(no content)You can switch modes using slash commands: Type /architect, /ask, /debug, /code, or /orchestrator at the beginning of your message.

### Token Optimization
Consider only using high Max Tokens / Max Thinking Tokens settings with modes like Architect and Debug, and keeping Code mode at 16k max tokens or less.(no content)Use Sticky Models to assign specialized AI models to different modes (reasoning model for planning, non-reasoning model for coding). Roo automatically switches to each mode's last-used model without manual selection.

### Multi-Model Workflow
The power of Roo Code lies in strategically assigning different Large Language Models (LLMs) to specialized "modes" within Roo Code, optimizing for performance, cost, and specific task requirements.(no content)The workflow is designed to mimic a highly efficient development team, with each "mode" acting as a specialized team member. It helps to start by generating a PRD (Project Requirements Document) and then use another LLM to generate a plan for each stage of the project.

### Custom Modes
Roo Code allows you to create custom modes to tailor Roo's behavior to specific tasks or workflows. Custom modes can be either global (available across all projects) or project-specific.(no content)You can share custom modes with your team to standardize workflows.

### General Tips
The extension's customizable Modes (Architect, Code, etc) keep the models on track and focused on the task at hand, without stepping outside of their boundaries. Lean on them depending on the task you're working on.

Based on my search, here's what I found about combining Claude Code, Cursor, and Roo Code workflows in 2025:

## Combined Workflow Overview

In 2025, developers are no longer limited to single-tool workflows‚Äîcombining Cursor's lightning-fast AI coding support with Claude Code's deep, strategic reasoning reshapes how apps get built.

### How the Tools Complement Each Other

**Claude Code Strengths:**
- Claude Code excels at providing long-term architectural insights‚Äîhelping you foresee scalability challenges before they arise.
- Claude Code is absolutely bonkers good when it comes to docs. It loves to create README.md, CLAUDE.md, project status files, roadmaps, etc.
- One developer notes they have a React component that's 18,000 lines long, and no AI agent has ever successfully updated this file except Claude Code.

**Cursor Strengths:**
- Cursor is great as a scaffolder. When the job is big, it's great at laying down structure. Plan Mode breaks the work into steps, proposes file-by-file edits, and nudges toward tests. It's opinionated in a way that makes large changes feel less like a cliff, more like a staircase.
- Cursor is a standalone, AI-augmented IDE forked from VS Code. It offers natural-language prompts, deep codebase querying, smart refactoring, and inline autocomplete.

**Roo Code (Cline Fork):**
- Roo Code (fork of Cline) is a VSCode Extension that's getting more and more popular. It's open-source, doesn't opine about the models, fully customizable, and has a really nice agent as well.
- You can plug your OpenRouter keys, Anthropic keys, and even connect it to Claude Code. Mode Switching is a killer feature‚Äîyou can Plan in the Architect mode, make it perfect, and then it will switch automatically to the Code mode and start executing the task.

### Practical Combined Workflow Strategies

One approach: give both sides the same prompt or plan, watch two minds work, then diff their opinions.(no content)Another workflow: Running Cursor with the $20/month plan combined with Claude Code ($100/month) as a terminal editor. This setup gives you the best of both worlds‚Äîuse Cursor's embedded models for simple questions about your codebase that don't need heavy reasoning, saving Claude Code tokens for the actual complex development work.(no content)A hybrid approach: prototype in Cursor for speed, then validate and produce an audited explanation using Claude for client deliverables. This combo gives both velocity and traceability.

### Setup Recommendations

Set up and integrate both tools efficiently using environment consistency, API authentication, and project context files like CLAUDE.md to maximize AI accuracy.(no content)For setup: Install Claude Code extension from Anthropic ($20/month Pro subscription includes Code usage, or Max $100 for brief coding project bursts). For Cursor: Download from cursor.com, import VS Code settings during setup ($20/month for Pro with unlimited completions). Git discipline: Create two branches immediately ‚Äì one for each tool.

### Key Takeaways

Teams may find that using both tools together delivers the best outcome.(no content)With Claude Code integration with Cursor, you don't have to choose ‚Äî Cursor becomes your IDE while Claude enhances reasoning in the background.

Based on my search, I found extensive information about Claude Code developer workflows, examples, and case studies. Here's a summary:

## Official Resources & Best Practices

Claude Code is a command line tool for agentic coding developed as a research project to give Anthropic engineers and researchers a more native way to integrate Claude into their coding workflows. It is intentionally low-level and unopinionated, providing close to raw model access without forcing specific workflows.

### Key Workflows from Anthropic

Test-driven development (TDD) is an Anthropic-favorite workflow for changes that are easily verifiable with tests. Ask Claude to write tests based on expected input/output pairs, and be explicit about doing TDD so it avoids creating mock implementations.(no content)For parallel development, Git worktrees work well with Claude Code‚Äîeach worktree has its own independent file state, making it perfect for parallel Claude Code sessions where changes in one worktree won't affect others.

## Real Developer Workflow Examples

### Creator's Workflow (Boris Cherny)
The Claude Code creator's team maintains a single file named CLAUDE.md in their git repository. "Anytime we see Claude do something incorrectly we add it to the CLAUDE.md, so Claude knows not to do it next time."(no content)He uses slash commands‚Äîcustom shortcuts checked into the project's repository‚Äîto handle complex operations with a single keystroke, including a command called /commit-push-pr which he invokes dozens of times daily.(no content)"Claude tests every single change I land to claude.ai/code using the Claude Chrome extension. It opens a browser, tests the UI, and iterates until the code works." He argues that giving the AI a way to verify its own work improves quality by "2-3x."

### Real Project Examples

One developer reported that for most tasks (5-8 steps) on their 16x Writer project, Claude Code was able to complete the task in one session within the context limit, though it still struggles with UI-related debugging like e2e testing.(no content)Another developer tested Claude Code in a Turbo + Next.js monorepo environment with multiple deployable apps, shared packages, infrastructure code, and common tooling.

### JIRA/Linear Integration
Some teams connect Claude Code to their ticket system via MCP servers. Claude can read the ticket, understand the requirements, implement the feature, update the ticket status, and even create new tickets if it finds bugs. The /ticket command handles the entire workflow.

### Automated Code Review Workflows
Teams have implemented code review agents that Claude runs after changes are made, following detailed checklists covering TypeScript strict mode, error handling, and more. When a PR goes up, GitHub Actions do a full PR review automatically.(no content)An automated code review system inspired by Anthropic's process implements dual-loop architecture with slash commands and GitHub Actions to automatically review PRs for syntax, completeness, style guide adherence, and bug detection.

## Community Resources & Tools

There's an "awesome-claude-code" curated list of slash-commands, CLAUDE.md files, CLI tools, and other resources for enhancing Claude Code workflows to help the community share knowledge and best practices.

Key community projects include:
- /tdd commands for Test-Driven Development principles, enforcing Red-Green-Refactor discipline
- Spec-driven development workflows (Requirements ‚Üí Design ‚Üí Tasks ‚Üí Implementation) and streamlined bug fix workflows (Report ‚Üí Analyze ‚Üí Fix ‚Üí Verify)
- Ralph for Claude Code - an autonomous AI development framework enabling iterative work with safety guardrails to prevent infinite loops

## Case Study Claims

One case study site claims: "Claude Code transformed our development process. What would have taken 2 years was completed in 6 months with higher quality than we ever imagined."

Based on my search results, I found information about Claude Code and flowcharts/decision trees, though the search didn't return a specific "when to use Claude Code" decision tree guide. Here's what I found:

## Claude Code and Flowchart/Decision Tree Capabilities

Claude Code excels at generating various types of diagrams and visualizations, leveraging both its understanding of data structures and its ability to create visual representations through multiple formats and tools. The tool can generate Mermaid diagrams for flowcharts, sequence diagrams, and system architecture visualizations directly within your development workflow.(no content)Claude Code understands different diagram types including system architecture diagrams, database entity-relationship diagrams, API flow charts, and user journey maps, adapting the visualization style to match the specific use case and technical requirements of your project.

## Using Claude to Create Flowcharts

You can turn written procedures into visual flowcharts that make complex processes easier to follow and share. Work with Claude to transform dense process documentation into flowing visual diagrams that show how your system actually works. Through conversation, you'll map out decision points, alternative paths, and volume distributions.(no content)To create flowcharts: "Enter the following prompt: 'Create a flowchart for: [specific topic]'. Claude will provide you with the Mermaid code. Go to mermaid(dot)live website, remove the code on the left side to paste yours, and watch your code turn into a flowchart!"

## Claude Skills Marketplace for Flowcharts

There's also a Claude Skills Marketplace on GitHub that includes flowchart capabilities:

It "activates when: User requests flowcharts, process diagrams, workflow visualizations, or decision trees" and can "create stunning HTML flowcharts and process flow diagrams with decision trees, color-coded stages."

If you're looking for a specific decision tree guide on when to use Claude Code itself (as opposed to other tools), that particular resource doesn't appear in the search results. Would you like me to search for something more specific?

Here are the search results for Claude Code best practices across TypeScript, Python, and React frameworks:

## Language Performance & Compatibility

Python and JavaScript/TypeScript show the strongest community satisfaction and performance. JavaScript & TypeScript show exceptional results, especially for React development.(no content)Developers consistently report high success rates with modern JavaScript frameworks and complex library integrations. Frameworks like React, Vue, Angular, Node.js, Express, and Next.js are well-supported with strengths in component analysis, async/await patterns, DOM manipulation, and event handling.

## Best Practices for TypeScript/React

To maximize benefits, familiarize yourself with Claude's prompt engineering. Craft prompts that include specifics like React version, TypeScript usage, or styling preferences. This precision leads to outputs that require minimal adjustments.(no content)Core React 19 patterns including hooks, Suspense, lazy loading, component structure, TypeScript best practices, and performance optimization are available as Claude Code skills. Use when working with React components, hooks, lazy loading, Suspense boundaries, or React-specific TypeScript patterns.

## Full-Stack Configuration (TypeScript + Python)

A heterogeneous stack with TypeScript/React frontend and Python backend means the AI assistant must seamlessly navigate TypeScript/React code and Python code, plus configuration files. The configuration ensures Claude has the right context and tools to handle both sides of the application.(no content)Claude Code activates the appropriate language server based on file extensions. For example, a project with Python backend and TypeScript frontend would use both pyright and vtsls simultaneously, with Claude seamlessly switching context as you navigate between files.

## Skills and Hooks for Best Practices

There is a modular code review skill for Claude Code covering React 19, Vue 3, Rust, TypeScript, Java, Python, CSS/Less/Sass, architecture design, and performance optimization. It provides language-specific patterns for React 19, Vue 3, Rust, TypeScript/JavaScript, Java, Python, and modern framework support including React Server Components, TanStack Query v5, Suspense & Streaming.(no content)A developer upgraded from "React 16 JS ‚Üí React 19 TypeScript, React Query v2 ‚Üí TanStack Query v5, React Router v4 w/ hashrouter ‚Üí TanStack Router w/ file-based routing, Material UI v4 ‚Üí MUI v7, all with strict adherence to best practices."

## Key Tips from Experienced Users

Claude Code adapts to your existing stack rather than requiring specific technologies. Focus on clear project structure and consistent patterns over language selection.(no content)Claude Code did not write tests until explicitly asked. # AI Coding Tools Workflow Recommendations

## Decision Framework: When to Use Each Tool

**Claude Code** is best for:
- "Actual features (important ones), bootstrap projects, and ideas"
- Complex tasks and bug finding
- Situations where you need maximized token usage without monthly caps

**Cursor** excels at:
- Quick tasks affecting one or two files
- Projects where you want to conserve requests for larger work
- Situations requiring file tagging across multiple documents

**Roo Code** shines when:
- You need structured planning before execution via "Architect mode"
- Working with multiple sub-tasks that require context preservation
- Seeking cost control through your own API keys

## Practical Workflow Examples

**Simultaneous Task Distribution**: The author notes you can "delegate different tasks (as long as they don't touch the same files) to Claude Code + Cursor + Roo Code at the same time," maximizing parallel productivity.

**Mode-Switching Strategy**: Roo Code's architecture allows planning in Architect mode, then automatic switching to Code mode for implementation‚Äîenabling cheaper model selection for execution phases while preserving planning quality.

**Context Management**: Start fresh chat sessions when feeling overwhelmed by accumulated context, rather than persisting in endless loops of corrections.

## Supporting Practices

Maintain identical project rules across all three tools using "Ruler" synchronization to prevent divergent AI behavior. Store reusable prompts for consistent output standards.

content.content:
# Decision Criteria: Roo Code vs. Claude Code

## Core Differences

**Claude Code** is a polished, terminal-based CLI tool from Anthropic, directly integrated with Claude models. **Roo Code** is an open-source, in-IDE agent (VS Code sidebar) offering model flexibility through "bring your own key" (BYOK).

## Selection Framework

### Choose Roo Code If You:
- Want deep IDE integration and real-time collaboration
- Value experimenting with multiple AI models (swap between GPT-4, Gemini, Claude)
- Prefer conversational planning before implementation
- Work with sprawling legacy systems requiring exploration
- Need custom modes for specific workflows (Code Reviewer, Test Writer)

### Choose Claude Code If You:
- Need enterprise-grade reliability and precision
- Want to automate tasks in CI/CD pipelines and GitHub Actions
- Prefer command-line workflows and scripting
- Work primarily with modern web stacks (React, Python, TypeScript)
- Prioritize surgical code changes over back-and-forth discussion

## Hybrid Approach

The article notes that many experienced developers use both tools strategically: Roo for daily in-editor work and architectural planning, Claude Code for specific high-powered tasks and automation.

## Key Trade-offs

| Factor | Roo Code | Claude Code |
|--------|----------|------------|
| Context | Project-wide analysis | 200k token window |
| Cost | Per-API-call model dependency | Potentially higher |
| Workflow | Collaborative/conversational | Command-driven/precise |
| Flexibility | Model-agnostic | Anthropic-locked |

input.prompt: Extract all best practices, common mistakes to avoid, and workflow recommendations from Anthropic's official guide. Include any decision frameworks, anti-patterns, and specific tips for different project types.
Extract all practical workflow recommendations, tips, and lessons learned about using Roo Code effectively. Include any workflow patterns, best practices, and common pitfalls to avoid.

content.content:
# Roo Code Workflow: Practical Recommendations & Best Practices

## Key Workflow Patterns

**Start with Architecture Mode**
Always begin in Architect mode to establish an implementation plan. This creates context for subsequent tasks and helps Roo maintain project consistency throughout development.

**Scope Management**
Keep individual task scope as small as possible. The quality of LLM responses degrades with larger inputs, so breaking work into discrete, focused objectives yields better results.

**Specificity in Prompts**
"Be as specific as possible when beginning a task. This means telling Roo what you want it to do and what you don't want it to do." Provide examples of desired and undesired outcomes to guide Roo's behavior effectively.

**Staged Mode Progression**
Transition from Architect to Code mode once plans are established. Use straightforward prompts like "Implement the plan described in the active context" since the memory bank maintains necessary context.

## Critical Best Practices

**Maintain Approval Gates**
Keep write approval enabled to prevent Roo from entering loops trying to fix issues you could resolve faster yourself. Review diffs before accepting changes.

**Manual Intervention Protocol**
When Roo struggles repeatedly with specific problems (like TypeScript type errors), stop and takeover manually rather than waiting for self-correction.

**Know Your Limits**
"Do not ask Roo to do anything you yourself don't know how to do." This prevents building unmaintainable code you cannot debug or guide later.

**Checkpoint Strategy**
Use checkpoints to rollback problematic changes when Roo's approach becomes incomprehensible or counterproductive.

## Essential Tools

**Project Memory System**
Implement Roo Code Memory Bank to persist context across tasks through structured files (activeContext.md, productContext.md, progress.md, decisionLog.md).

**Context Mentions**
Leverage "@" references to selectively include files, line ranges, terminal output, git changes, and open tabs without overwhelming Roo with unnecessary information.

**MCP Servers**
Connect to external tools like PostgreSQL MCP servers to expand Roo's capabilities for database interaction and other specialized tasks.

## Common Pitfalls to Avoid

- Requesting work beyond your comprehension level
- Approving all writes automatically without review
- Assigning overly broad tasks in single sessions
- Failing to stop and takeover when Roo repeatedly fails
- Not maintaining consistent project context between tasks

content.content:
# Claude Code Best Practices Guide

## Setup & Configuration

**CLAUDE.md Files**
Create special markdown files to document project-specific context. Store in repo root (checked into git), parent directories, or home folder (~/.claude/CLAUDE.md). Include bash commands, utility functions, code style guidelines, testing instructions, and repo etiquette. Keep content concise and refine iteratively by testing what produces best instruction-following.

Use the `#` key during sessions to have Claude automatically incorporate instructions into relevant CLAUDE.md files.

**Permission Management**
Configure allowed tools via:
- "Always allow" responses during sessions
- `/permissions` command to modify allowlist
- Manual editing of `.claude/settings.json` or `~/.claude.json`
- `--allowedTools` CLI flag for session-specific access

Use `--dangerously-skip-permissions` only in isolated containers without internet access.

**Tool Availability**
Install the `gh` CLI for GitHub integration. Document custom bash tools in CLAUDE.md. Connect MCP servers via project config, global config, or checked-in `.mcp.json` files.

---

## Effective Workflows

**Explore ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Code ‚Üí Commit**
1. Have Claude read relevant files without writing code initially
2. Request planning with thinking modes ("think" through "ultrathink" for increased computation)
3. Implement the solution with explicit verification requests
4. Commit results and update documentation

Steps 1-2 are critical‚Äîskipping them often leads to rushed implementations.

**Test-Driven Development**
1. Write tests based on input/output pairs (explicitly state you're doing TDD)
2. Confirm tests fail without implementation
3. Commit the tests
4. Implement code iteratively until all tests pass
5. Commit the working implementation

Claude performs best with clear targets: tests, visual mocks, or concrete outputs.

**Visual Iteration**
1. Provide screenshot capability (Puppeteer MCP, iOS simulator MCP, or manual pasting)
2. Share design mocks
3. Have Claude implement, screenshot, and iterate
4. Commit when satisfied

Multiple iterations typically yield significantly better results than first attempts.

**Safe YOLO Mode**
Use `claude --dangerously-skip-permissions` for uninterrupted work on safe tasks (lint fixes, boilerplate generation). Only in containerized environments without internet access.

---

## Optimization Techniques

**Be Specific in Instructions**
Vague requests like "add tests for foo.py" underperform. Instead: "write a new test case for foo.py covering the edge case where the user is logged out, avoid mocks."

Clarity on first attempt reduces course corrections.

**Provide Visual Context**
- Paste screenshots (cmd+ctrl+shift+4 on macOS, then ctrl+v)
- Drag-drop images directly
- Reference image file paths

Critical for UI development and visual analysis tasks.

**Reference Files and URLs**
- Tab-complete to quickly reference repository resources
- Paste URLs for Claude to fetch and read
- Use `/permissions` to allowlist domains and avoid repeated prompts

**Course Correction Tools**
- Plan before coding; require approval before implementation
- Press Escape to interrupt any phase while preserving context
- Double-tap Escape to jump back in history and explore alternatives
- Request undo operations when needed

**Context Management**
Use `/clear` frequently during long sessions to reset context window. Improves performance and prevents distraction from irrelevant conversation.

**Checklists for Complex Tasks**
For migrations, bulk lint fixes, or complex scripts, have Claude write errors to a Markdown checklist, then fix issues one-by-one while checking off progress.

**Data Input Methods**
- Copy/paste directly (most common)
- Pipe into Claude Code (`cat foo.txt | claude`)
- Request Claude pull data via bash, MCP tools, or custom commands
- Have Claude read files or fetch URLs (including images)

---

## Common Workflows by Use Case

**Codebase Onboarding**
Ask conversational questions as you would during pair programming: "How does logging work?" Claude explores the codebase agentically. No special prompting needed. This has become Anthropic's core onboarding method.

**Git Operations**
- Search git history to answer design questions
- Generate contextual commit messages
- Handle complex operations (reverts, rebase conflicts, patch grafting)
- Many Anthropic engineers use Claude for 90%+ of git interactions

**GitHub Interactions**
- Create PRs using "pr" shorthand
- Implement one-shot fixes for code review comments
- Fix failing builds or linter warnings
- Categorize and triage open issues

**Jupyter Notebooks**
Open Claude Code and .ipynb files side-by-side in VS Code. Claude can interpret outputs including images. Request aesthetic improvements before sharing with colleagues‚Äîexplicitly mentioning "aesthetically pleasing" helps.

---

## Multi-Claude Workflows

**Parallel Review Process**
1. Claude writes code
2. `/clear` or new terminal with second Claude
3. Second Claude reviews/tests first Claude's work
4. Third Claude (or /clear again) refines based on feedback

Separation of context often yields better results than single-Claude execution.

**Multiple Repository Checkouts**
- Create 3-4 git checkouts in separate folders
- Open each in terminal tabs
- Start Claude in each with different tasks
- Cycle through to approve/deny permissions

**Git Worktrees** (Preferred)
- `git worktree add ../project-feature-a feature-a`
- `cd ../project-feature-a && claude`
- Lighter weight than multiple checkouts
- Enables independent concurrent tasks

Tips: Use consistent naming, maintain one tab per worktree, enable iTerm2 notifications, separate IDE windows per worktree, cleanup with `git worktree remove`.

---

## Headless Mode & Automation

**Basic Usage**
Use `-p` flag with prompt for non-interactive contexts. Add `--output-format stream-json` for structured output.

Note: Headless mode doesn't persist between sessions.

**Fanning Out Pattern**
For large migrations/analyses (2k+ files):
1. Have Claude generate task list
2. Loop through tasks, calling Claude programmatically with specific task and allowed tools
3. Refine prompt iteratively

Example: `claude -p "migrate foo.py from React to Vue..."`

**Pipelining Pattern**
Integrate into existing data pipelines:
```
claude -p "<prompt>" --json | your_command
```

Use `--verbose` flag for debugging; turn off in production.

---

## Anti-Patterns & Gotchas

- **Skipping planning**: Jumping straight to coding reduces solution quality for complex problems
- **Over-broad CLAUDE.md files**: Add content iteratively; test effectiveness before keeping
- **Ignoring context windows**: Long sessions degrade performance; use `/clear` between tasks
- **Missing visual targets**: Claude iterates better with tests, screenshots, or mocks as reference points
- **Vague instructions**: Generic requests underperform; be specific about constraints and edge cases
- **Single-Claude large tasks**: Breaking work across multiple Claude instances often improves quality

---

## Key Principles

1. **Flexibility over prescription**: No single "right" workflow; adapt based on task type
2. **Iteration as strength**: 2-3 iterations typically beat first-pass solutions
3. **Context as currency**: Explicit instructions and visual references maximize effectiveness
4. **Separation of concerns**: Multiple Claude instances on independent tasks reduces errors
5. **Safety by default**: Conservative permissions reduce risk; whitelist safe operations

content.text:
Now I have comprehensive research. Let me compile this into a detailed response.

# Practical Workflows Combining Claude Code and Roo Code

Based on extensive research from developer experiences, official documentation, and community discussions, here is a comprehensive guide for developers looking to optimize their workflows with both Claude Code and Roo Code.

---

## 1. How Developers Actually Use Both Tools Together

The most effective developers treat these tools as complementary rather than competing. According to [Arsturn's comparison](https://www.arsturn.com/blog/roo-vs-claude-code-which-ai-is-best-for-large-codebases):

**Roo Code for Daily Work:**
- In-editor exploration and architectural planning
- Conversational back-and-forth during development
- Mode switching between Architect and Code phases

**Claude Code for Precision Tasks:**
- Complex refactoring requiring surgical accuracy
- CI/CD automation and GitHub Actions integration
- Terminal-based scripting and batch operations

**Parallel Execution Pattern** (from [Pedro Martins' workflow](https://nikuscs.com/blog/10-ai-workflow-with-claude-code-roocode-gpt/)):
You can delegate different tasks to Claude Code, Cursor, and Roo Code simultaneously, provided they do not touch the same files.

---

## 2. Task Handoff Strategies Between Tools

### Context Preservation Methods

**CLAUDE.md Files:**
Teams maintain a single CLAUDE.md file in their git repository. According to [VentureBeat's coverage](https://venturebeat.com/technology/the-creator-of-claude-code-just-revealed-his-workflow-and-developers-are), "Anytime we see Claude do something incorrectly we add it to the CLAUDE.md, so Claude knows not to do it next time."

**Roo Code Memory Bank:**
Use Roo's structured memory system (activeContext.md, productContext.md, progress.md, decisionLog.md) to persist context across sessions.

### Smart Handoff Protocol

From [Smart Handoff for Claude Code](https://blog.skinnyandbald.com/never-lose-your-flow-smart-handoff-for-claude-code/):
- Run handoff commands when reaching 60-70% context usage
- Document current state before context compaction
- Use `/compact` to trigger manual context refresh when Claude gets lost

### Session Teleportation (Claude Code v2.1.0)
According to [VentureBeat](https://venturebeat.com/orchestration/claude-code-2-1-0-arrives-with-smoother-workflows-and-smarter-agents), the `/teleport` and `/remote-env` commands allow developers to resume sessions between local terminals and web interfaces.

## 3. Project Type Recommendations

### Web Development (Frontend)
| Task | Recommended Tool | Rationale |
|------|------------------|-----------|
| Component planning | Roo Code (Architect mode) | Structured planning with mode switching |
| React/Vue implementation | Either | Both handle modern frameworks well |
| Complex refactoring | Claude Code | Surgical precision, 77.2% SWE-bench success |
| UI iteration with screenshots | Claude Code | Superior visual iteration workflow |

### Backend Development
| Task | Recommended Tool | Rationale |
|------|------------------|-----------|
| API design | Roo Code (Architect mode) | Read-only planning phase |
| Database migrations | Claude Code | Checklist-based execution |
| CI/CD automation | Claude Code | Scriptable CLI integration |
| Bug investigation | Roo Code (Debug mode) | Conversational exploration |

### Mobile Development
Both tools work for mobile development, though the research shows less specific mobile workflow documentation. General recommendation: use Roo Code for planning and Claude Code for implementation.

### Large/Legacy Codebases
According to [Arsturn](https://www.arsturn.com/blog/roo-vs-claude-code-which-ai-is-best-for-large-codebases):
- **Roo Code**: Better for sprawling legacy systems requiring exploration
- **Claude Code**: Better when you need precise, surgical changes

From [ClaudeLog](https://claudelog.com/faqs/what-programming-languages-work-best-with-claude-code/) and [full-stack configuration guides](https://htdocs.dev/posts/claude-code-full-stack-configuration-guide/):

**Python:** Strong support in both tools. Claude Code offers LSP integration with pyright.

From [Roo Code documentation](https://docs.roocode.com/basic-usage/using-modes):
- Use reasoning models (o3) for Architect mode
- Use faster models (Claude Sonnet) for Code mode
- Configure different Max Tokens for different modes (16k for Code mode recommended)

## 6. When to Use API Directly vs Subscription Plans

### Cost Thresholds

From [Hacker News discussion](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45077941) and [PromptLayer analysis](https://blog.promptlayer.com/claude-code-pricing-how-to-save-money/):

| Monthly Usage | Recommendation |
|---------------|----------------|
| < $20 | API with prompt caching |
| $20-$100 | Claude Pro subscription ($20/mo) |
| $100-$200 | Claude Max ($100/mo or $200/mo) |
| > $200 | API with batch processing + caching |

**Key Insight:** One user tracked their usage with `--view monthly` and found they would have spent only $70.46 on API while paying $100/month for Max.

### Subscription Options

From [IntuitionLabs pricing guide](https://intuitionlabs.ai/articles/claude-pricing-plans-api-costs):
- **Pro**: $20/month - Good starting point
- **Max 5x**: $100/month - 5x usage limits
- **Max 20x**: $200/month - Full Opus 4.5 access

### Roo Code Cost Model
Roo Code uses BYOK (Bring Your Own Key). Real-world testing shows approximately $50 in tokens for comprehensive feature testing according to [Arsturn](https://www.arsturn.com/blog/roo-vs-claude-code-which-ai-is-best-for-large-codebases).

## 7. Cost Optimization Strategies for Heavy Users

From [AI Engineering Report](https://www.aiengineering.report/p/the-hidden-costs-of-claude-code-token) and [PromptLayer](https://blog.promptlayer.com/claude-code-pricing-how-to-save-money/):

### Technical Optimizations
1. **Prompt Caching**: Save up to 90% on input token costs
2. **Batch Processing**: 50% savings on output tokens
3. **Model Selection**: Use Sonnet for routine tasks, Opus for complex reasoning

### Workflow Optimizations
1. **Use `/clear` frequently** to reset context windows
2. **Start fresh sessions** rather than persisting through corrections
3. **Use subagents** to preserve main context
4. **Delegate simple tasks** to cheaper models in Roo Code

### Hybrid Approach
From [developer recommendations](https://yomotherboard.com/question/should-i-stick-with-roo-or-make-the-switch-to-claude-code/):
Get the cheapest subscription and switch to API when you hit limits.

## 8. Real Workflow Examples

### Example 1: Feature Development (from [Anthropic's best practices](https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/claude-code-best-practices))

**Explore - Plan - Code - Commit:**
1. Have Claude read relevant files without writing
2. Request planning with thinking modes
3. Implement with explicit verification
4. Commit and update documentation

### Example 2: Test-Driven Development

From [Anthropic's TDD workflow](https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/claude-code-best-practices):
1. Write tests based on input/output pairs
2. Confirm tests fail
3. Commit tests
4. Implement until tests pass
5. Commit implementation

### Example 3: Multi-Tool Parallel Workflow

From [Pedro Martins](https://nikuscs.com/blog/10-ai-workflow-with-claude-code-roocode-gpt/):
- Claude Code: Core feature implementation
- Cursor: Quick single-file edits
- Roo Code: Architectural planning in Architect mode

### Example 4: Roo Code Mode Progression

From [Atomic Object](https://spin.atomicobject.com/roo-code-ai-assisted-development/):
1. Start in Architect mode for planning
2. Transition to Code mode: "Implement the plan described in active context"
3. Switch to Debug mode when issues arise
4. Use `/architect`, `/code`, `/debug` commands

### Example 5: JIRA/Linear Integration

According to [awesome-claude-code](https://github.com/hesreallyhim/awesome-claude-code):
Some teams use MCP servers to connect Claude Code to ticket systems. Claude reads tickets, implements features, updates status, and creates new tickets for discovered bugs.

## 9. Common Mistakes and Anti-Patterns to Avoid

### Anti-Pattern 1: Skipping Planning
From [Anthropic](https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/claude-code-best-practices):
Jumping straight to code is like building without blueprints. Use Shift+Tab to switch to planning mode.

### Anti-Pattern 2: Context Pollution
From [PubNub subagent best practices](https://www.pubnub.com/blog/best-practices-for-claude-code-sub-agents/):
One Claude session for everything leads to concerns bleeding together. Deploy specialized subagents.

### Anti-Pattern 3: Ignoring Existing Patterns
From [Brandon Casci's experience](https://www.brandoncasci.com/2025/07/30/from-chaos-to-control-teaching-claude-code-consistency.html):
Claude doesn't automatically know your patterns. Be explicit about conventions in CLAUDE.md.

### Anti-Pattern 4: Modifying Tests Carelessly
From [DoltHub gotchas](https://www.dolthub.com/blog/2025-06-30-claude-code-gotchas/):
Claude Code is not bashful about modifying tests to assert wrong behavior. Review test file changes carefully.

### Anti-Pattern 5: Over-Broad CLAUDE.md Files
From [Anthropic](https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/claude-code-best-practices):
Add content iteratively; test effectiveness before keeping.

### Anti-Pattern 6: Not Knowing When to Takeover
From [Atomic Object](https://spin.atomicobject.com/roo-code-ai-assisted-development/):
When Roo struggles repeatedly, stop and takeover manually rather than waiting for self-correction.

### Anti-Pattern 7: Requesting Beyond Your Understanding
From [Atomic Object](https://spin.atomicobject.com/roo-code-ai-assisted-development/):
Do not ask Roo to do anything you yourself do not know how to do. This prevents unmaintainable code.

## 10. Decision Tree for Choosing the Right Tool

### Primary Decision: IDE vs Terminal Preference

```
Start Here
    |
    v
Do you prefer working in VS Code IDE?
    |
    +--[Yes]--> Roo Code as primary, Claude Code for automation
    |
    +--[No/Terminal preferred]--> Claude Code as primary
```

### Task-Type Decision Framework

| Question | If Yes | If No |
|----------|--------|-------|
| Is this exploratory/architectural planning? | Roo Code (Architect mode) | Continue |
| Does it require CI/CD integration? | Claude Code | Continue |
| Is it a single-file quick edit? | Cursor or Roo Code | Continue |
| Do you need model flexibility? | Roo Code (BYOK) | Claude Code |
| Is precision critical (no tolerance for mistakes)? | Claude Code | Either |
| Are you working with legacy code requiring exploration? | Roo Code | Either |

### When to Use Both Together

From [Arsturn](https://www.arsturn.com/blog/roo-vs-claude-code-which-ai-is-best-for-large-codebases):

**Use Roo Code for:**
- Day-to-day in-editor coding
- Architectural planning
- Conversational exploration
- Mode-specific workflows

**Use Claude Code for:**
- High-powered specific tasks
- Automation and scripting
- CI/CD pipeline integration
- Terminal-based batch operations

### Cost-Optimized Decision Path

```
Monthly AI Coding Budget?
    |
    +--[< $20]--> Roo Code with cheaper API models
    |
    +--[$20-$50]--> Claude Pro + Roo Code with Sonnet
    |
    +--[$50-$100]--> Claude Pro + API overflow
    |
    +--[$100+]--> Claude Max or API with batch processing
```

## Summary: The Optimal Combined Workflow

Based on all research, here is the recommended workflow for developers using both tools:

1. **Planning Phase**: Use Roo Code in Architect mode for system design and planning documents

2. **Implementation Phase**: 
   - Simple/routine: Roo Code (Code mode)
   - Complex/precision: Claude Code
   - Parallel tasks: Distribute across both tools (non-overlapping files)

3. **Review Phase**: Use Claude Code for automated PR reviews via GitHub Actions

4. **Context Management**:
   - Maintain CLAUDE.md in git for shared learning
   - Use Roo Code memory bank for session persistence
   - Clear contexts frequently to prevent degradation

5. **Cost Control**:
   - Start with Pro subscription
   - Track usage with `--view monthly`
   - Adjust based on actual consumption patterns
